abstract.t: This document proposes defines a new mechanism for discovering Kerberos services using DNS. This new mechanism extends the mechanism already defined in Kerberos V5 and has four goals. First, reduce the number of DNS queries required to discover a Kerberos KDC. Second, provide DNS administrators more control over client behavior. Third, provide support for discovery of the MS-KKDCP transport. Fourth, define a discovery procedure for Kerberos password services.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Section 7.2.3 of Kerberos V5 defines a procedure for discovering a KDC based on DNS SRV records. This method has three drawbacks. First, two DNS queries are required to locate a single service (one for UDP and one for TCP). Second, specifying UDP and TCP in separate records means that the DNS administrator has no control over client preferences for TCP or UDP. Third, any new transports for reaching the KDC (such as MS-KKDCP) will require new records and additional DNS queries.

The Kerberos Password protocol has no defined procedure for discovery similar to the KDC method described above. Implementations have largely chosen a similar method to section 7.2.3 of Kerberos V5, inheriting the same drawbacks outlined above.
This RFC defines three new URI DNS records; one each for KDC, Kerberos Password, and Kerberos Admin service discovery.

section.title: Document Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Realm to Domain Translation
section.t: This document does not define a new mechanism for translating Kerberos realms to DNS domains. The existing mechanism as defined in section 7.2.3.1 of Kerberos V5 MUST be followed.

section.title: Kerberos V5 KDC Service Discovery
section.t: In order to discover a KDC service location, the client MUST query the following URI DNS record (REALM indicates the translation of the Kerberos realm to a DNS domain):
_kerberos.REALM
TTL, Class, URI, Priority, Weight and Target have the standard meanings as defined in RFC 2782 and the URI DNS record type. Target SHOULD contain the URI format specified in this document.

section.title: Kerberos Password Service Discovery
section.t: In order to discover a password service location, the client MUST query the following URI DNS record (REALM indicates the translation of the Kerberos realm to a DNS domain):
_kpasswd.REALM
TTL, Class, URI, Priority, Weight and Target have the standard meanings as defined in RFC 2782 and the URI DNS record type. Target SHOULD contain the URI format specified in this document.

section.title: Kerberos Admin Service Discovery
section.t: In order to discover an admin service location, the client MUST query the following URI DNS record (REALM indicates the translation of the Kerberos realm to a DNS domain):
_kerberos-adm.REALM
TTL, Class, URI, Priority, Weight and Target have the standard meanings as defined in RFC 2782 and the URI DNS record type. Target SHOULD contain the URI format specified in this document.
The Kerberos admin protocol is not standardized and clients using URI to locate admin servers MUST be aware of the protocol used by the server implementation.

section.title: Required URI Format
section.t: The following URI format MUST be supported by clients.
The URI format is comprised of ASCII text fields delimited by the colon (":") character:
krb5srv:[flags]:transport-type:transport-info
See for examples.

section.title: Scheme
section.t: The initial field identifies the URI scheme. It MUST be the string value "krb5srv". It is recommended that implementations process this field in a case-insensitive manner.

section.title: Flags
section.t: This field contains a sequence of zero or more characters, used individually to convey server attributes or feature support (e.g., "xyz" indicates support for features x, y, and z.) for the purpose of organizing the lookup results. Implementations SHOULD process this field in a case-insensitive manner.
This field MUST be present even when no flags are provided, appearing as two colons seperating the scheme and transport fields (e.g., "krb5srv::tcp:hostname").
Flag characters that are unused or unknown to the client SHOULD be ignored.

Flag values SHOULD be registered with IANA under the Kerberos Server Discovery Flags registry that is defined in this document. See for the initially registered flags and information on allocating new flags.

section.title: Master Flag
section.t: The "m" flag indicates that the server is a "master", which is expected to be an authoritative source for Kerberos database information, and is not subject to propagation delay.

section.title: Transport Type
section.t: This field contains a string value indicating the transport method to use when contacting the server specified by the URI entry. Implementations SHOULD process this field in a case-insensitive manner.

Transport values SHOULD be registered with IANA under the Kerberos Server Discovery Transport Types registry that is defined in this document. See for the initially registered transports and information on allocating new transport values.

section.title: Transport Info
section.t: This field contains information specific to the transport. It may contain sub-fields where such are defined in the transport specification. The case-sensitivity of this field can vary between sub-fields, so implementations SHOULD follow the case rules as defined by the transport specification.
In the case of a MS-KKDCP URL, the default virtual directory "/KdcProxy" path extension MUST be specified in the URL and MUST NOT be implicitly assumed by clients.

section.title: Relationship to Existing Mechanism
section.t: If an existing discovery protocol is supported by a client, the client SHOULD perform the URI lookup as defined in this document first. If no URI record is found, the client MAY attempt discovery using another protocol.

section.title: Kerberos Server Discovery Transport Types
section.t: This section specifies the IANA "Kerberos Server Discovery Transport Types" registry. New values are to be registered according to the "Specification Required" policy outlined in . This registry records the value, description, transport-info format, default ports, and a reference for each type.

A description of the transport-info format expected by the transport.
Three numbers, each within the range of 1-65535, specifying the default ports for KDC, Admin, and Password services, in that order.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security implication of using DNS URI records is identical to that of using DNS for any Kerberos service or host mapping; without secure DNS the results can be forged. The same precautions regarding the use of insecure DNS with Kerberos outlined in RFC 4120 should be followed.
